ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I got better at close reading and writing analytical papers. I also did some reflection on American culture and what makes it distinct from other nations.

Great opportunity to read through some of the best works in American literature. Fun and challenging regardless of your level (whether you are visiting these texts for the first or for the fifth time).
I read an eclectic spanning of american literature, talked through important analytic points in class discussion, and meditated more acutely on the themes of these works in the written assignments.
Definitely learning how to read texts closely and in depth, as well as how to analyze based on evidence and incorporation of criticism.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: I liked that we engaged with many different types of texts (poetry, novels, memoirs, etc.)
Weaknesses: I think that course discussion could have been organized a bit better so that certain students did not dominate the conversation and that we got to talk about all the required readings for each class.

Strengths: Reading list was fabulous. Framing for essays and comments on essays were really helpful. This class significantly improved my writing; and you have a lot of room to write on what most interests you. Prof. Hammer (particularly on essays) is fabulous and incredibly kind. Such a joy for a 9am class. Only thing I might change about this course is White Noise on the syllabus and maybe Don't Let me be Lonely.

have only one type of essay assigned and having to write it three times was difficult, especially because i struggle with close readings. although each one was an opportunity to get better, i do not think that this is always the best mode of essay writing to engage in literary analysis. it would've been ideal to have more creative analytic exercises...
Strengths: definitely all of the class discussions and hearing other students interpretations of texts.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend the course to someone starting out with the English department at Yale, but it is very broad otherwise.

Yes, 100% would recommend and with definitely take it with Professor Hammer. Our section was really small which meant you could really take discussion in a direction that interested you (although, admittedly, sometimes made it difficult to go deeply if not everyone was prepared).
I would only take it as part of the american studies requirements; otherwise it isn't particularly targeted towards my literary interests, and I only enjoyed at most half of the syllabus.
Definitely; you get a bigger picture of types of American literature, and you learn how to have conversations with your peers about texts, essays, and more.
